supporting_text: The concept of 'One Health' emphasizes that no sector of society can solve this problem by itself - the solutions have to be sought in close collaboration between human health, animal health and agriculture, and also other sectors.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including raising awareness and improving education on AMR.
The NAP includes actions aimed at improving the responsible use of antimicrobials in veterinary settings and animal husbandry.
The NAP addresses the need to improve environmental surveillance and reduce emissions of untreated sewage and antimicrobial production waste.
The NAP includes strategies for improving the use of antimicrobials in agriculture and ensuring food safety.
At the end, there is also a Monitoring and Evaluation part to facilitate following up of the implementation of the Plan.
The NAP outlines milestones for significant changes in awareness levels by mid-2020 and end of 2022.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The document broadly touches on what budget source should be covering costs, but does not specify allocations.
The document does not contain a detailed assessment of future budget requirements.
The national intersectoral coordination group or the formal way of responding to the AMR problem provides the concept of 'One Health' and monitors the implementation of strategic measures.
The NAP includes actions to review and update current legislation and regulations regarding antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes actions to include AMR and related topics as a core component of professional education and training.
The NAP includes establishing public communications programs targeting various audiences to raise awareness about AMR.
The NAP mentions collaboration with WHO, FAO, and OIE in the development and implementation of the plan.
The NAP includes setting up a national surveillance system for antimicrobial resistance and improving data collection.
The NAP emphasizes the need for improved surveillance and reporting mechanisms for AMR.
The NAP includes improving infection prevention and control through adequate measures for water supply, sanitation, and hygiene.
The NAP includes actions to ensure compliance with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes actions to strengthen the pharmaceutical supply chain and regulate antibiotic use.
The NAP includes strategies to ensure rational use of antibiotics in both human and veterinary sectors.
The NAP emphasizes the need for operational research priorities for responsible use of antimicrobial agents.
